misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student correctly understands the necessary steps for a right circular shift: 1) Save the last element (which would otherwise be overwritten). 2) Iterate backward from the end (index n-1) to index 1, assigning arr[i] = arr[i-1], which effectively shifts elements right one position. 3) Assign the saved last element to the first position (index 0). The student's code correctly implements this standard algorithm.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap. The student's mental model aligns with the actual execution of the code for array manipulation and circular shifting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Correct output based on the problem requirements.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student implemented the correct algorithm for a right array shift with wrap-around. They correctly stored the last element (arr[n-1]), iterated backwards (from n-1 down to 1) to shift elements right (arr[i] = arr[i-1]), and finally placed the stored last element into arr[0].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap detected; the student's mental model aligns with the execution model for array manipulation, iteration, and variable assignment in Java.
